examples: His irrational fear of flying prevented him from accepting the job overseas.
The market's irrational exuberance led to a devastating crash.

persistence.definition: Firm or obstinate continuance in a course of action despite difficulty or opposition.
examples: Her persistence in the face of repeated rejection finally led to a breakthrough.
Success in research often comes down to patience and persistence.
persistence.metaphor: Persistence is water on stone; given enough time, it can reshape anything.

revelation.definition: A surprising and previously unknown fact that is disclosed; a moment of sudden insight or understanding.
examples: The revelation that the trusted advisor had been lying shocked everyone.
Traveling alone was a revelation; she discovered strengths she never knew she had.

authorship.definition: The state or fact of being the author of a work; the origin of a piece of writing or creation.
examples: The authorship of the anonymous manuscript remained a mystery for centuries.
She took pride in the authorship of the report that changed company policy.

bodyguard.definition: A person employed to protect someone from physical harm or danger.
examples: The celebrity traveled everywhere with a team of bodyguards.
He jokingly called his loyal dog his personal bodyguard.

comprehensibility.definition: The quality of being understandable; clarity of meaning.
examples: The comprehensibility of the instructions determined whether customers could assemble the product.
Good scientific writing balances technical accuracy with comprehensibility.

exemplification.definition: The act of illustrating by example; a typical instance that demonstrates something.
examples: Her career was an exemplification of what hard work and dedication can achieve.
The teacher used real-world exemplification to make abstract concepts concrete.

metonymy.definition: A figure of speech in which one thing is referred to by the name of something closely associated with it.
examples: Saying 'the White House announced' is a metonymy, using the building to represent the president's administration.
Metonymy is everywhere in everyday speech, from 'Wall Street' for finance to 'Hollywood' for the film industry.

brevity.definition: Concise and exact use of words; shortness of time or duration.
examples: The brevity of his speech was refreshing after hours of long-winded presentations.
Brevity is essential in good writing; say what you mean and stop.
brevity.metaphor: Brevity is the soul of wit, and the skeleton key to effective communication.

tether.definition: A rope or chain used to tie something to a fixed point; the limit of one's resources or patience.
examples: The dog was kept on a tether in the yard to prevent it from wandering.
After months of delays, she was at the end of her tether with the contractor.

inexorable.definition: Impossible to stop or prevent; relentless and unyielding.
examples: The inexorable march of technology continues to transform every industry.
She faced the inexorable decline of her health with extraordinary grace.
inexorable.metaphor: Time is inexorable, a river that carries everything downstream regardless of protest.

impede.definition: To delay or prevent by obstructing; to hinder progress.
examples: Heavy regulations can impede innovation in emerging industries.
The fallen tree impeded traffic on the narrow mountain road for hours.

unctuous.definition: Excessively smooth, flattering, or ingratiating in manner; oily.
examples: The unctuous salesman's flattery did nothing to win her trust.
His unctuous charm masked a calculating personality that few people saw through.

debit.definition: An entry recording a sum owed; a charge against a bank account.
examples: The unexpected debit on her account turned out to be an automatic subscription renewal.
Every credit in life comes with a debit somewhere down the line.

infiltrate.definition: To enter or gain access to an organization or place secretly and gradually, especially to acquire information.
examples: The undercover agent managed to infiltrate the criminal network over several months.
Misinformation can infiltrate even the most respected news organizations.

rely.definition: To depend on with full trust or confidence.
examples: You can always rely on her to tell you the truth, even when it is uncomfortable.
The village relied on the river for drinking water and irrigation.

stratify.definition: To form or arrange into distinct layers or levels; to divide into social classes or categories.
examples: Geological forces stratify rock into visible layers over millions of years.
Education systems can inadvertently stratify students based on socioeconomic background.

forbearance.definition: Patient self-control and restraint; tolerance shown toward someone or something that tests one's patience.
examples: Her forbearance in dealing with difficult clients was truly remarkable.
The lender offered a period of forbearance, allowing the borrower to delay payments.

populist.definition: A person who supports or claims to represent the interests of ordinary people against an elite establishment.
examples: The populist candidate promised to fight corruption and give power back to the people.
Critics argued that the populist movement was long on rhetoric but short on practical solutions.

bask.definition: To lie exposed to warmth and light, especially sunlight; to enjoy and take pleasure in something.
examples: The cat basked in the warm patch of sunlight on the living room floor.
She basked in the glow of her team's success after months of hard work.

onus.definition: A duty, responsibility, or burden; the obligation to prove something.
examples: The onus is on the prosecution to prove guilt beyond a reasonable doubt.
The onus of caring for the aging parents fell entirely on the youngest sibling.

individuation.definition: The process of becoming an individual distinct from others; the development of a unique identity.
examples: Adolescence is a critical period for individuation, as young people seek to define themselves.
Jung described individuation as the lifelong process of integrating the conscious and unconscious mind.

significance.definition: The quality of being worthy of attention; importance or meaning.
examples: The significance of the discovery was not fully understood until decades later.
She struggled to find significance in a job that felt meaningless.

insight.definition: A deep and accurate understanding of something; the ability to see clearly into the nature of things.
examples: Her insight into human motivation made her an exceptional therapist.
The book offers valuable insight into the challenges facing modern education.
insight.metaphor: Insight is a flashlight in a dark room, suddenly revealing what was always there.

precision.definition: The quality of being exact, accurate, and careful; meticulous attention to detail.
examples: The surgeon operated with remarkable precision, minimizing any risk of complication.
The precision of his language left no room for misinterpretation.

postpone.definition: To cause or arrange for something to take place at a later time than originally planned; to delay.
examples: They had to postpone the outdoor wedding due to the incoming hurricane.
She kept postponing the difficult conversation until there was no more time left.

pandemonium.definition: Wild and noisy disorder; uproar and chaos.
examples: Pandemonium erupted in the stadium when the home team scored the winning goal.
The announcement of layoffs caused pandemonium in the office.

unreal.definition: Not real; existing only in the imagination; so remarkable as to seem impossible.
examples: The views from the mountaintop were so stunning they seemed almost unreal.
The speed at which the situation deteriorated felt unreal.

encroachment.definition: The gradual intrusion on someone's territory, rights, or domain.
examples: Urban encroachment on farmland has accelerated dramatically in recent decades.
She resented the encroachment of work into her personal life.

friable.definition: Easily crumbled; having a loose, powdery texture.
examples: The friable soil made it easy to dig but prone to erosion.
The ancient manuscript was so friable that it had to be handled with extreme care.
friable.metaphor: Trust, once broken, becomes friable; it crumbles at the slightest touch.

lacklustre.definition: Lacking brightness, vitality, or enthusiasm; dull and uninspired.
examples: The team delivered a lacklustre performance that disappointed the sold-out crowd.
After months of lacklustre sales, the company decided to revamp its marketing strategy.
lacklustre.metaphor: His once-sharp eyes had gone lacklustre, as though someone had dimmed the lights behind them.

presumptuous.definition: Overstepping appropriate bounds; showing excessive confidence or boldness without proper justification.
examples: It would be presumptuous of me to offer advice on a subject I know nothing about.
The intern made the presumptuous decision to email the CEO directly.

tremulous.definition: Shaking or quivering slightly, often from nervousness, weakness, or emotion.
examples: Her tremulous voice betrayed the fear she was trying so hard to conceal.
He reached out with a tremulous hand to accept the lifetime achievement award.
tremulous.metaphor: The candle flame gave a tremulous light, as uncertain as the hopes of those gathered around it.

courtship.definition: The period or process of seeking affection with the intent of establishing a romantic relationship.
examples: Their courtship lasted three years before he finally proposed on a mountaintop.
In the age of dating apps, traditional courtship rituals have largely disappeared.
courtship.metaphor: The courtship between the company and its investors was a delicate dance of promises and projections.

monolith.definition: A large single block of stone, or a massive, uniform, and seemingly immovable structure or entity.
examples: The ancient monolith stood in the field, its origins a mystery to archaeologists.
The tech giant had become a monolith that smaller companies found impossible to challenge.
monolith.metaphor: The old bureaucracy was a monolith, resistant to every attempt at reform.

circumspection.definition: Careful consideration of all circumstances and consequences before acting; prudence and caution.
examples: The diplomat handled the negotiations with remarkable circumspection.
A lack of circumspection in financial planning can lead to devastating consequences.

susceptibility.definition: The quality of being easily influenced, affected, or harmed by something.
examples: Children have a greater susceptibility to infections during the winter months.
Her susceptibility to flattery made her an easy target for manipulative people.

crystallize.definition: To form into crystals; figuratively, to become clear and definite.
examples: The sugar solution will crystallize if you let it cool slowly overnight.
After weeks of vague discussions, the plan finally began to crystallize into something actionable.
crystallize.metaphor: Her scattered thoughts crystallized into a single, brilliant idea that changed everything.

ambidextrous.definition: Able to use both hands with equal skill; figuratively, unusually versatile.
examples: The ambidextrous pitcher could throw equally well with either arm.
She was intellectually ambidextrous, equally comfortable with mathematics and poetry.

coherency.definition: The quality of being logical, consistent, and forming a unified whole.
examples: The essay lacked coherency, jumping from topic to topic without clear transitions.
Sleep deprivation gradually eroded the coherency of his arguments during the debate.

coincidence.definition: A remarkable occurrence of events at the same time by chance, without apparent causal connection.
examples: It was a strange coincidence that they both chose the same obscure restaurant on the same night.
Some dismiss synchronicities as mere coincidence, while others see deeper meaning.

inscribe.definition: To write, carve, or engrave words on a surface; to dedicate a book or work to someone.
examples: The jeweler offered to inscribe a personal message inside the wedding band.
She inscribed the first copy of her novel to the teacher who had believed in her.
inscribe.metaphor: Every hardship inscribed a new lesson on the surface of her character.

corrode.definition: To gradually wear away or destroy, especially by chemical action; to deteriorate over time.
examples: Salt water will corrode metal fixtures if they are not properly protected.
Years of resentment had corroded their once-close friendship beyond repair.
corrode.metaphor: Jealousy corrodes the soul like acid eats through steel.

polemic.definition: A strong verbal or written attack on opinions or beliefs; a controversial argument or debate.
examples: His latest book is a fierce polemic against the failures of modern education.
The editorial was less an objective analysis than a political polemic.

stratum.definition: A layer or level, especially one of several parallel layers; a level of society.
examples: Geologists identified a stratum of volcanic ash dating back millions of years.
The novel explores every stratum of Victorian society, from aristocracy to the working poor.
stratum.metaphor: Beneath the stratum of her calm exterior lay deep reserves of determination.

avert.definition: To turn away or prevent something undesirable from happening.
examples: Quick thinking by the pilot helped avert a potential disaster.
She averted her eyes from the gruesome scene, unable to watch any longer.

indispensable.definition: Absolutely necessary; so important that one cannot manage without it.
examples: Clean water is indispensable to human survival.
She quickly became indispensable to the organization, handling tasks no one else could manage.

fragrance.definition: A pleasant, sweet smell; a delightful scent or aroma.
examples: The fragrance of jasmine drifted through the open window on a warm summer evening.
Her signature fragrance lingered in the room long after she had left.
fragrance.metaphor: The fragrance of nostalgia wafted through his mind as he flipped through the old photo album.

urgency.definition: The quality of requiring immediate action or attention; pressing importance.
examples: The urgency in the doctor's voice told them the situation was serious.
Climate scientists continue to stress the urgency of reducing carbon emissions.

outlive.definition: To live longer than another person or thing; to survive beyond.
examples: She outlived her husband by twenty years and spent them traveling the world.
Some ideas outlive the civilizations that created them.
outlive.metaphor: His reputation outlived his actual accomplishments, growing into legend.

migratory.definition: Relating to or characterized by migration; moving from one region to another, especially seasonally.
examples: Migratory birds travel thousands of miles each year following ancient routes.
The migratory workforce moves with the harvest seasons.
migratory.metaphor: Her migratory attention never settled on one subject for long.

stakeholder.definition: A person or group with an interest or concern in something, especially a business or enterprise.
examples: All stakeholders were invited to voice their concerns about the new development.
Effective leaders consider the needs of every stakeholder before making major decisions.

voluptuous.definition: Relating to or characterized by luxury, sensual pleasure, or fullness of form.
examples: The voluptuous curves of the baroque architecture drew admirers from around the world.
She sank into the voluptuous comfort of the velvet armchair after a long day.
voluptuous.metaphor: The sunset painted the sky in voluptuous shades of crimson and gold.

specialize.definition: To concentrate on and become expert in a particular subject, skill, or activity.
examples: After medical school, she decided to specialize in pediatric cardiology.
The firm specializes in intellectual property law for tech startups.

predominance.definition: The state of being greater in number, influence, or importance; superiority or dominance.
examples: The predominance of English as a global language continues to shape international business.
His predominance in the field of quantum physics was unchallenged for decades.

accrue.definition: To accumulate or grow over time, especially referring to benefits, interest, or advantages.
examples: Interest will accrue on the account at a rate of three percent per year.
The benefits of regular exercise accrue gradually over months and years.
accrue.metaphor: Wisdom accrues like compound interest -- slowly at first, then with gathering momentum.

inconspicuous.definition: Not clearly visible or noticeable; not attracting attention.
examples: He chose an inconspicuous seat in the back corner of the restaurant.
The security cameras were deliberately inconspicuous, blending into the ceiling.

gratify.definition: To give pleasure or satisfaction to; to indulge or fulfill a desire.
examples: It gratified her enormously to see her students succeed in their careers.
He could not resist the urge to gratify his curiosity by opening the sealed envelope.

exorcise.definition: To drive out an evil spirit; figuratively, to rid oneself of a troubling memory or influence.
examples: The shaman performed an elaborate ritual to exorcise the spirit from the house.
Writing the memoir helped her exorcise the demons of her troubled childhood.
exorcise.metaphor: She needed to exorcise the ghost of her past relationship before she could move forward.

pining.definition: Feeling deep longing, yearning, or sorrow, especially for something lost or unattainable.
examples: He spent months in a pining state after she moved to another country.
The pining melody of the violin echoed through the empty concert hall.

narrator.definition: A person who tells a story or gives an account of events, especially in a book, film, or broadcast.
examples: The unreliable narrator kept readers guessing about what was actually true.
Morgan Freeman has become one of the most beloved narrators in documentary filmmaking.
narrator.metaphor: We are all narrators of our own lives, editing the story as we go.

ambassador.definition: A diplomatic official of the highest rank representing their country abroad; any authorized representative.
examples: The ambassador presented her credentials to the head of state upon arriving.
She served as an ambassador for the brand, representing its values at every public event.

promiscuous.definition: Having many sexual partners indiscriminately; also, lacking order or discrimination.
examples: The tabloids scrutinized the celebrity for his promiscuous lifestyle.
The garden was a promiscuous mix of wildflowers, herbs, and vegetables.

fragility.definition: The quality of being easily broken, damaged, or destroyed; delicacy and vulnerability.
examples: The fragility of the ancient manuscript required handlers to wear cotton gloves.
The crisis exposed the fragility of the global supply chain.
fragility.metaphor: There was a fragility to her composure, like a thin sheet of ice over deep water.

impiety.definition: Lack of reverence or respect, especially toward things considered sacred.
examples: His casual jokes about religion were seen as impiety by the congregation.
The philosopher argued that true impiety lies in acting without conscience.

derail.definition: To cause a train to leave its tracks; figuratively, to divert something from its intended course.
examples: A fallen tree on the tracks nearly derailed the passenger train.
One careless remark was enough to derail months of delicate negotiations.

servile.definition: Excessively willing to serve or please others; submissive and obsequious in a degrading way.
examples: His servile behavior around the boss made his coworkers lose respect for him.
The servile tone of the letter disgusted her -- she wanted honesty, not flattery.

intrigue.definition: A secret scheme or plot; also, the quality of arousing curiosity or fascination.
examples: The novel is full of political intrigue set against the backdrop of Renaissance Italy.
The mysterious stranger at the party aroused her intrigue immediately.

abominable.definition: Extremely unpleasant, hateful, or morally reprehensible; causing disgust.
examples: The conditions in the overcrowded prison were absolutely abominable.
His abominable treatment of his employees led to a class-action lawsuit.

generosity.definition: The quality of being willing to give freely; liberality in giving money, time, or kindness.
examples: Her generosity toward the local shelter helped feed hundreds of families each year.
The generosity of spirit he showed to his rivals earned him universal respect.

workmanship.definition: The degree of skill and quality evident in the way something is made or executed.
examples: The workmanship of the hand-carved furniture was truly exceptional.
Customers are willing to pay a premium for superior workmanship.

layman.definition: A person without professional or specialized knowledge in a particular subject.
examples: The scientist wrote the book in language a layman could easily understand.
To a layman, the legal jargon in the contract was nearly incomprehensible.

unrelenting.definition: Not yielding in strength, severity, or determination; relentless and persistent.
examples: The unrelenting heat of the desert sun made every step a struggle.
Her unrelenting pursuit of justice inspired a generation of civil rights activists.
unrelenting.metaphor: Time is an unrelenting tide that carries all things forward.

puppet.definition: A figure manipulated by strings or by hand; a person or entity controlled by another.
examples: The children squealed with delight as the puppet danced across the tiny stage.
Critics accused the new president of being a puppet of the military establishment.

recant.definition: To formally withdraw or renounce a previously held belief or statement.
examples: Under pressure from the church, the scientist was forced to recant his theories.
She refused to recant her testimony despite threats from the defendant.

opus.definition: A musical composition or set of compositions; more broadly, any significant artistic work.
examples: The filmmaker considered this documentary to be his magnum opus.
Her latest opus, a sweeping historical novel, took seven years to complete.

revamp.definition: To renovate, redo, or give new and improved form to something.
examples: The restaurant decided to revamp its menu to attract a younger clientele.
The city revamped its public transit system with new buses and extended routes.

covet.definition: To desire eagerly something that belongs to another; to yearn possessively for.
examples: She coveted the corner office with its panoramic view of the city skyline.
Collectors around the world covet first-edition copies of that rare novel.

slog.definition: To work hard and steadily at a difficult or tedious task; to trudge or plod.
examples: They slogged through the muddy trail for hours before reaching the campsite.
She slogged away at the report all weekend to meet the Monday deadline.

rectify.definition: To put right; to correct an error, fault, or undesirable situation.
examples: The company promised to rectify the billing error within 24 hours.
He took immediate steps to rectify the misunderstanding before it caused further damage.

prosaic.definition: Lacking imagination or excitement; dull and commonplace; unpoetic.
examples: After years of exotic travel, she found suburban life disappointingly prosaic.
His prosaic description of the Grand Canyon failed to capture any of its grandeur.
prosaic.metaphor: Even the most prosaic daily routine can become poetry when viewed through the lens of gratitude.

commodore.definition: A naval officer ranking above a captain; also, the senior captain of a fleet or the chief officer of a yacht club.
examples: The commodore took command of the squadron during the critical naval exercise.
As commodore of the yacht club, she organized the annual regatta.

entice.definition: To attract or tempt by offering something appealing; to lure.
examples: The aroma of freshly baked bread enticed passersby into the bakery.
The company used generous signing bonuses to entice top talent away from competitors.
entice.metaphor: Spring entices the dormant earth back to life with warm whispers of sunlight.

sleek.definition: Smooth, glossy, and streamlined in appearance; elegant and well-groomed.
examples: The sleek sports car turned heads as it glided through the city streets.
Her sleek hair fell like a dark curtain around her shoulders.

bilingual.definition: Able to speak two languages fluently; expressed in or involving two languages.
examples: Growing up in a bilingual household gave her a natural advantage in language learning.
The bilingual signs at the airport helped international travelers navigate easily.

sizable.definition: Fairly large; of considerable size or extent.
examples: The company made a sizable investment in renewable energy technology.
A sizable crowd had gathered outside the courthouse awaiting the verdict.

austerity.definition: Severity of self-discipline and avoidance of luxury; strict economy, especially enforced by government policy.
examples: The wartime austerity meant families had to ration even basic necessities.
Years of government austerity measures left public services severely underfunded.
austerity.metaphor: The room had a monastic austerity, stripped of every comfort and distraction.

frolic.definition: A playful, lively outing or activity; carefree fun and merriment.
examples: The children had a frolic in the autumn leaves, laughing and tumbling about.
What started as a harmless frolic turned into an unforgettable adventure.

minutia.definition: A minor or trivial detail (usually used in the plural: minutiae).
examples: She had an extraordinary memory for the minutiae of historical events.
Do not let the minutiae of daily life distract you from the bigger picture.

oligarchy.definition: A form of government in which power is held by a small, elite group of people.
examples: Critics warned that the country was sliding from democracy into oligarchy.
The tech industry has been accused of forming a modern oligarchy with outsized influence on politics.

quip.definition: A witty or clever remark, often made spontaneously.
examples: Her quip about the budget meeting being more exciting than a root canal got a big laugh.
He was known for his quick quips that could lighten even the tensest situation.

terrorism.definition: The use of violence and intimidation, especially against civilians, to achieve political or ideological aims.
examples: International cooperation is essential in the fight against terrorism.
The new legislation aimed to cut off the financial networks that fund terrorism.

suffrage.definition: The right to vote in political elections.
examples: The suffrage movement fought for decades to secure voting rights for women.
Universal suffrage is considered a cornerstone of modern democracy.

agility.definition: The ability to move quickly and easily; also, the capacity to think and adapt rapidly.
examples: The gymnast demonstrated remarkable agility on the balance beam.
Business agility -- the ability to pivot quickly -- is essential in a fast-changing market.
agility.metaphor: Mental agility is the acrobatics of the mind, leaping between ideas with grace.

inconclusive.definition: Not leading to a definite conclusion or result; leaving doubt unresolved.
examples: The investigation produced inconclusive results, forcing detectives to reopen the case.
The medical tests were inconclusive, so the doctor ordered additional scans.

picaresque.definition: Relating to fiction that depicts the adventures of a roguish but appealing hero.
examples: The novel follows a picaresque journey through the underbelly of 18th-century London.
His memoir reads like a picaresque tale, full of colorful characters and improbable escapes.

grieving.definition: Experiencing deep sorrow, especially over the death or loss of someone.
examples: The grieving widow stood silently at the graveside long after the ceremony ended.
Counseling services were made available to the grieving community after the tragedy.

subservience.definition: Willingness to obey others unquestioningly; excessive submissiveness or servility.
examples: His blind subservience to authority made him an unreliable ally.
The culture of subservience in the organization stifled creativity and honest feedback.

wane.definition: To decrease gradually in size, intensity, or importance; to diminish.
examples: Public interest in the scandal began to wane after several weeks.
As the afternoon wore on, her enthusiasm for the project started to wane.
wane.metaphor: His influence waned like a setting moon, casting ever-longer shadows before disappearing.

colossus.definition: A person or thing of enormous size, power, or importance; a giant.
examples: Shakespeare was a colossus of English literature whose influence endures to this day.
The corporation grew into a colossus that dominated the entire industry.
colossus.metaphor: She bestrode the courtroom like a colossus, commanding the attention of everyone present.

personalize.definition: To design or tailor something to meet individual needs or preferences; to make personal.
examples: The app uses algorithms to personalize content recommendations for each user.
She personalized each thank-you card with a handwritten note.

flagship.definition: The ship carrying the commander of a fleet; figuratively, the best or most important item in a group.
examples: The new downtown campus will serve as the flagship of the university system.
Their flagship product accounts for nearly half of total revenue.

hallow.definition: To make holy or sacred; to honor as sacred; to consecrate.
examples: The ancient site was hallowed ground, revered by pilgrims for centuries.
Lincoln urged the nation to hallow the memory of those who had sacrificed their lives.

irony.definition: The expression of meaning using language that normally means the opposite; a state of affairs contrary to what one expects.
examples: The irony of a fire station burning down was not lost on the local newspaper.
She delivered the criticism with such subtle irony that he mistook it for a compliment.

chicane.definition: The use of deceptive tricks or subterfuge to achieve a goal; trickery and sophistry.
examples: The lawyer was known for legal chicane rather than honest argumentation.
Through a combination of chicane and charm, he managed to avoid every accusation.

recount.definition: To tell someone about something; to narrate the details of an experience or event.
examples: She recounted her journey across the Sahara with vivid detail and dry humor.
The survivors recounted the harrowing events of the shipwreck to the rescue team.

uplift.definition: To raise to a higher moral, social, or intellectual level; to inspire and elevate.
examples: Her speech was designed to uplift the spirits of the struggling community.
Great art has the power to uplift the human soul beyond ordinary experience.

startle.definition: To cause to feel sudden shock or alarm; to surprise abruptly.
examples: The loud crack of thunder startled everyone in the quiet library.
His candor startled the audience, who were accustomed to polished political speeches.

averse.definition: Having a strong dislike or opposition to something; reluctant.
examples: She was averse to taking unnecessary risks with the company funds.
He was not averse to a glass of wine with dinner, though he rarely drank otherwise.

dissipate.definition: To scatter or cause to vanish; to squander or waste resources frivolously.
examples: The morning fog dissipated as the sun climbed higher in the sky.
He dissipated his inheritance on lavish parties and reckless investments.
dissipate.metaphor: Her anger dissipated like smoke, leaving behind only a faint residue of sadness.

replica.definition: An exact copy or reproduction of something, especially a work of art.
examples: The museum displayed a meticulous replica of the original Rosetta Stone.
He built a half-scale replica of a Viking longship in his backyard.

subside.definition: To become less intense, active, or severe; to sink to a lower level.
examples: The floodwaters began to subside after three days of clear weather.
Once the initial panic subsided, they were able to think clearly about their options.

irrepressible.definition: Impossible to restrain or control; bursting with energy or enthusiasm.
examples: Her irrepressible laughter was contagious, filling the room with warmth.
The irrepressible optimism of youth can be a powerful force for change.

unshakable.definition: Firm and unwavering; impossible to weaken or disturb.
examples: Her unshakable faith sustained her through years of hardship.
He maintained an unshakable composure even when confronted with hostile questioning.

paramour.definition: A lover, especially the illicit partner of a married person.
examples: The scandal broke when the senator was photographed with his paramour.
In the novel, the queen kept a secret paramour hidden in the palace.

modernism.definition: A broad movement in art, architecture, and literature that deliberately breaks with classical and traditional forms.
examples: Modernism challenged every assumption about what art could and should be.
The building is a masterpiece of modernism, all clean lines and open spaces.

frankness.definition: The quality of being open, honest, and direct in speech; candor.
examples: His frankness about the financial situation earned him the trust of the board.
She appreciated his frankness, even when his words were hard to hear.

incoherent.definition: Lacking logical or meaningful connection; unclear and difficult to understand.
examples: The patient became increasingly incoherent as the fever worsened.
His argument was so incoherent that even his supporters struggled to defend it.

brilliancy.definition: Exceptional brightness, splendor, or intellectual sharpness.
examples: The brilliancy of the diamond under the spotlight took her breath away.
The brilliancy of her legal reasoning set her apart from every other attorney in the firm.

cull.definition: To select and remove from a group; to pick out the best or eliminate the weakest.
examples: The editor culled the best essays from hundreds of submissions.
Farmers sometimes cull weaker animals to maintain the health of the herd.

clan.definition: A close-knit group of families united under a common ancestor or leader; any tightly bonded group.
examples: The Scottish clan gathered every summer for a reunion at the ancestral castle.
The startup world has its own clan of true believers who evangelize disruption.

abstinence.definition: The practice of voluntarily refraining from indulging in something, especially food, drink, or pleasure.
examples: His abstinence from alcohol lasted over ten years.
The monk practiced abstinence as a form of spiritual discipline.

prologue.definition: An introductory section of a literary or musical work; an event or action leading to something larger.
examples: The prologue of the novel sets the scene in a war-torn village.
That first meeting was merely the prologue to a lifelong friendship.

disrespectful.definition: Showing a lack of respect or courtesy; rude and inconsiderate.
examples: Talking during the ceremony was considered deeply disrespectful.
His disrespectful tone during the meeting alienated several potential allies.

recurrence.definition: The act of occurring again; a repeated return of something, especially something unwelcome.
examples: The doctor warned about the possibility of a recurrence of the illness.
The recurrence of the same mistakes in policy planning frustrated the committee.

cyclone.definition: A violent rotating windstorm with low atmospheric pressure at its center; a powerful destructive force.
examples: The cyclone devastated the coastal town, flattening hundreds of buildings.
Preparations for the approaching cyclone began days before it made landfall.
cyclone.metaphor: The new CEO swept through the organization like a cyclone, reorganizing every department.

impossibility.definition: The state of being impossible; something that cannot be done or achieved.
examples: What seemed like an impossibility a decade ago is now everyday technology.
She refused to accept the impossibility of the task and found a way through.

indiscretion.definition: A lack of good judgment; an act that is unwise or shows poor discretion, especially in personal conduct.
examples: A youthful indiscretion nearly cost him his political career decades later.
She paid dearly for a single moment of indiscretion at the office party.

protrude.definition: To extend beyond or above a surface; to stick out or project.
examples: A jagged rock protruded from the shallow water, posing a hazard to swimmers.
His eyes seemed to protrude with surprise when he heard the unexpected news.

linchpin.definition: A person or thing vital to an enterprise or organization; the essential element holding things together.
examples: She was the linchpin of the entire operation -- without her, nothing ran smoothly.
Trust is the linchpin of any successful partnership.

stipulate.definition: To specify as a condition or requirement in an agreement or arrangement.
examples: The contract stipulated that all work must be completed within six months.
She stipulated that her donation remain anonymous.

arbitrate.definition: To act as a neutral judge in a dispute; to settle a disagreement through mediation.
examples: An independent panel was brought in to arbitrate the labor dispute.
She was often called upon to arbitrate disagreements between her siblings.

reprehensible.definition: Deserving strong criticism or condemnation; morally blameworthy.
examples: The cover-up was even more reprehensible than the original offense.
Exploiting vulnerable people for profit is utterly reprehensible.

chastise.definition: To rebuke or punish severely, especially for wrongdoing; to scold harshly.
examples: The coach chastised the players for their lack of effort in the second half.
She chastised herself for not speaking up when she had the chance.

masterly.definition: Showing great skill or command; performed with the expertise of a master.
examples: Her masterly handling of the crisis saved the company from bankruptcy.
The conductor gave a masterly interpretation of the symphony.

subvert.definition: To undermine the power and authority of an established system or institution; to overthrow or corrupt.
examples: The hackers attempted to subvert the election by spreading disinformation online.
The artist sought to subvert traditional notions of beauty in her provocative exhibit.

pagan.definition: A person holding religious beliefs other than those of the major world religions; historically, one who is not Christian, Muslim, or Jewish.
examples: Many Christmas traditions have roots in pagan winter solstice celebrations.
The ancient pagans worshipped a pantheon of gods connected to the natural world.

corrosion.definition: The gradual destruction of a material, especially metal, by chemical reaction; figuratively, the slow deterioration of something.
examples: Salt air accelerates the corrosion of iron structures near the coast.
The corrosion of public trust in institutions is a growing concern for democracies.

constancy.definition: The quality of being unchanging, faithful, or resolute; steadfastness in purpose or devotion.
examples: His constancy through years of adversity was nothing short of heroic.
The constancy of her love was the one anchor in his turbulent life.
constancy.metaphor: Her constancy was the North Star by which he navigated every storm.

extravagance.definition: Excessive spending or wastefulness; lack of restraint in spending money or using resources.
examples: The extravagance of the royal wedding drew criticism from taxpayers.
After years of extravagance, he found himself drowning in debt.

myopic.definition: Nearsighted; figuratively, lacking foresight or intellectual insight.
examples: The myopic focus on quarterly profits blinded the company to long-term risks.
Critics called the policy myopic, arguing it addressed symptoms rather than root causes.

arouse.definition: To awaken or stir into action; to evoke a feeling or response.
examples: The documentary aroused public outrage over environmental pollution.
Her passionate speech aroused the crowd to action.

greedy.definition: Having an intense and selfish desire for something, especially wealth or food.
examples: The greedy landlord raised rents far beyond what his tenants could afford.
She watched with greedy eyes as the dessert tray was wheeled to the table.

acuity.definition: Sharpness or keenness, especially of thought, vision, or perception.
examples: Her mental acuity remained sharp well into her nineties.
The test measures visual acuity by having patients read letters at various distances.

momentary.definition: Lasting for only a moment; very brief and fleeting.
examples: There was a momentary pause before the audience erupted in applause.
A momentary lapse in concentration cost the goalkeeper the match.

ritual.definition: A set of actions performed according to a prescribed order, especially as part of a ceremony; a habitual practice.
examples: The morning ritual of coffee and journaling helped her start each day with clarity.
Ancient harvest rituals celebrated the bounty of the earth.

converge.definition: To come together from different directions to meet at a single point; to tend toward a common result.
examples: Thousands of protesters converged on the capital from every corner of the country.
Multiple lines of evidence converge on the same conclusion.

suggestive.definition: Tending to suggest or hint at something; evocative or indicative, sometimes with a sexual connotation.
examples: The painting was suggestive of a deeper emotional turmoil beneath the calm surface.
His suggestive remarks made several colleagues uncomfortable.

imprison.definition: To confine someone in prison; to restrict or trap someone or something.
examples: The activist was imprisoned for speaking out against the regime.
She felt imprisoned by the expectations her family placed on her.
imprison.metaphor: Grief imprisoned him in a cell of his own making, with no key in sight.

gestation.definition: The process of carrying offspring in the womb; figuratively, the development of a plan or idea over time.
examples: The gestation period for elephants is approximately 22 months.
The novel had a long gestation, taking over a decade from initial concept to publication.

headway.definition: Forward movement or progress, especially when difficult.
examples: After weeks of stalled negotiations, the two sides finally made headway on a deal.
We struggled to make headway against the strong current.

itinerary.definition: A planned route or schedule of travel; a detailed plan for a journey.
examples: The travel agent prepared a detailed itinerary covering every day of the two-week trip.
She deviated from the itinerary to explore a charming village they stumbled upon.

incomplete.definition: Not having all necessary parts; not fully finished or developed.
examples: The detective knew the picture was still incomplete without the missing evidence.
An incomplete understanding of the problem led to a flawed solution.

inconceivable.definition: Not capable of being imagined or believed; beyond comprehension.
examples: The scale of the destruction was almost inconceivable to those who had not witnessed it.
It was inconceivable to her that anyone would turn down such a generous offer.

extrinsic.definition: Coming from outside; not inherently part of something; external.
examples: The study examined both intrinsic motivation and extrinsic rewards like bonuses.
Extrinsic factors such as market conditions played a role in the decision.

determinism.definition: The philosophical doctrine that all events are determined by previously existing causes, leaving no room for free will.
examples: Hard determinism argues that every human decision is the inevitable result of prior causes.
The debate between determinism and free will has occupied philosophers for centuries.

sensationalism.definition: The use of shocking or provocative material to generate public interest or excitement, especially in media.
examples: The tabloid was criticized for its sensationalism in covering the celebrity trial.
Good journalism should inform, not resort to sensationalism for clicks and views.

undergo.definition: To experience or be subjected to something, typically something unpleasant or demanding.
examples: She will undergo surgery next week to repair the damaged ligament.
The city underwent a dramatic transformation over the past two decades.

dryad.definition: In Greek mythology, a nymph or spirit inhabiting a tree or forest.
examples: The poet imagined dryads dancing among the ancient oaks at twilight.
The sculpture depicted a dryad emerging from the trunk of a gnarled tree.
dryad.metaphor: She moved through the forest like a dryad, at one with every leaf and shadow.

subsidence.definition: The gradual sinking or settling of an area of land; the process of becoming less intense.
examples: Mining operations caused significant subsidence in the surrounding neighborhoods.
The subsidence of tensions between the two countries allowed trade to resume.

nickelodeon.definition: An early type of movie theater charging five cents for admission; also, a jukebox or coin-operated entertainment machine.
examples: The nickelodeon was where many Americans first experienced the magic of moving pictures.
The restored nickelodeon in the museum still plays silent films on weekends.

flick.definition: To make a quick, light, snapping movement; to strike with a quick motion.
examples: She flicked the light switch and the room flooded with warm amber light.
He flicked a crumb off his jacket before stepping onto the stage.

snatch.definition: To seize quickly and eagerly; to grab abruptly.
examples: The thief snatched her purse and disappeared into the crowd.
She snatched a few hours of sleep before the early morning flight.

bedfellow.definition: A person who shares a bed; figuratively, an associate or ally, especially an unexpected one.
examples: The crisis made strange bedfellows of political rivals who normally opposed each other.
Poverty and crime are common bedfellows in neglected urban neighborhoods.

bachelor.definition: An unmarried man; also, a person who has earned a first university degree.
examples: He remained a confirmed bachelor until he met her at a friend's wedding.
She earned her bachelor's degree in engineering before pursuing a master's.

orchestral.definition: Relating to or composed for an orchestra; having the richness and complexity of orchestral music.
examples: The orchestral score elevated the film from good to unforgettable.
She arranged the folk melody for a full orchestral performance.

simony.definition: The buying or selling of religious privileges, positions, or pardons.
examples: The medieval church was plagued by simony, with wealthy families purchasing bishoprics.
Accusations of simony contributed to the growing calls for religious reform.

balustrade.definition: A railing supported by short pillars, typically along the edge of a balcony, terrace, or staircase.
examples: She leaned against the marble balustrade, gazing out over the moonlit garden.
The ornate balustrade along the grand staircase was a masterpiece of ironwork.

impervious.definition: Not allowing anything to pass through; unable to be affected or influenced.
examples: The material is impervious to water, making it ideal for outdoor gear.
She seemed impervious to criticism, never letting negative comments rattle her confidence.

behemoth.definition: A huge or monstrous creature; anything enormously large and powerful.
examples: The tech behemoth reported annual revenues exceeding the GDP of many countries.
The ancient text described a behemoth that shook the earth with every step.

mendacious.definition: Not telling the truth; lying or habitually dishonest.
examples: The mendacious politician was eventually caught in a web of his own lies.
Her mendacious account of events unraveled under cross-examination.

wayside.definition: The edge of a road or path; used figuratively in the phrase "fall by the wayside" meaning to fail or be abandoned.
examples: Many promising startups fall by the wayside within their first two years.
Wildflowers bloomed along the wayside, adding color to the dusty road.

indigenous.definition: Originating or occurring naturally in a particular place; native.
examples: The indigenous peoples of the Amazon have protected the rainforest for millennia.
Several indigenous plant species are now endangered due to urban development.

cosmopolitan.definition: Familiar with and at ease in many different countries and cultures; free from local prejudices.
examples: Her cosmopolitan upbringing, spanning four continents, gave her a unique worldview.
The cosmopolitan atmosphere of the city attracted artists from around the globe.

millennium.definition: A period of one thousand years; an era of great happiness or achievement.
examples: The dawn of the new millennium was celebrated with fireworks around the world.
Scholars study how civilizations rose and fell over the course of a millennium.

militancy.definition: Aggressive or combative vigor in support of a cause; readiness to fight.
examples: The growing militancy of the protest movement alarmed government officials.
There was a quiet militancy in her insistence that justice be served.

profitable.definition: Yielding profit or beneficial results; advantageous or rewarding.
examples: The investment proved far more profitable than anyone had predicted.
It was a profitable conversation that gave her several new ideas for the project.

sedative.definition: A substance that calms or induces sleep; anything that soothes or tranquilizes.
examples: The doctor prescribed a mild sedative to help her sleep after the accident.
The gentle rhythm of the waves acted as a natural sedative.

profoundly.definition: To a great depth or degree; in a way that has a deep impact.
examples: The experience profoundly changed her understanding of the world.
He was profoundly moved by the generosity of complete strangers.

witchcraft.definition: The practice of magic or sorcery; figuratively, an irresistible or enchanting influence.
examples: Accusations of witchcraft led to tragic persecution in colonial New England.
Her ability to persuade even the most stubborn opponents seemed like witchcraft.

jeer.definition: To make rude, mocking remarks; to taunt or scoff at someone.
examples: The crowd jeered at the politician as he tried to deliver his speech.
Rather than jeering from the sidelines, she offered constructive criticism.

woeful.definition: Full of sorrow or misery; also, very bad or inadequate.
examples: The refugees told woeful tales of displacement and loss.
The team put in a woeful performance, losing by the largest margin in their history.

conquest.definition: The act of conquering by force; a victory or achievement gained through effort.
examples: The Norman Conquest of England in 1066 reshaped the course of European history.
The conquest of polio stands as one of modern medicine's greatest triumphs.

sentinel.definition: A guard or lookout; a person or thing that watches or stands guard.
examples: The lone sentinel stood at the castle gate through the long, cold night.
The lighthouse served as a sentinel, warning ships of the dangerous rocks.
sentinel.metaphor: The ancient oak stood as a sentinel at the edge of the property, witness to generations.

laden.definition: Heavily loaded or burdened; weighed down with a large amount of something.
examples: The branches were laden with ripe apples, bending almost to the ground.
She arrived at the party laden with gifts for every guest.
laden.metaphor: His voice was laden with unspoken regret.

prognosis.definition: A forecast of the likely course of a disease or situation; a prediction of outcome.
examples: The doctor gave a cautiously optimistic prognosis after reviewing the test results.
The economic prognosis for the region remains uncertain.

ungrateful.definition: Not feeling or showing gratitude; failing to appreciate kindness or favors received.
examples: She felt hurt by her ungrateful children who never acknowledged her sacrifices.
It would be ungrateful to complain about such a generous offer.

fertility.definition: The ability to produce offspring or abundant growth; richness and productivity.
examples: The fertility of the river valley made it ideal for farming.
Advances in fertility treatments have given hope to millions of couples.
fertility.metaphor: The fertility of her imagination produced one brilliant idea after another.

liberalism.definition: A political and social philosophy that emphasizes individual rights, equality, and open-mindedness.
examples: Classical liberalism championed free markets and limited government intervention.
The university has long been considered a bastion of liberalism.

hospitality.definition: The friendly and generous reception and entertainment of guests or strangers.
examples: The warmth of their hospitality made us feel like family from the moment we arrived.
The hospitality industry was among the hardest hit during the economic downturn.

mouthpiece.definition: The part of an instrument placed in or near the mouth; a spokesperson or representative.
examples: The saxophone player replaced the worn mouthpiece to improve his tone.
The senator was widely seen as a mouthpiece for the oil industry.

moody.definition: Given to unpredictable changes of mood; temperamental and often gloomy.
examples: The moody teenager retreated to her room, refusing to speak to anyone.
The moody weather alternated between brilliant sunshine and sudden downpours.

homicide.definition: The killing of one person by another; the act itself or the department that investigates it.
examples: The detective transferred to the homicide division after ten years in narcotics.
The case was ruled a justifiable homicide after a thorough investigation.

collude.definition: To secretly cooperate for a fraudulent or deceitful purpose; to conspire.
examples: The two companies were found to have colluded to fix prices and eliminate competition.
Evidence suggested that officials had colluded with the smuggling ring.

bravura.definition: A brilliant or daring performance or display of skill; great technical virtuosity.
examples: The pianist delivered a bravura performance that left the audience speechless.
Her closing argument was a piece of legal bravura that swayed the entire jury.

hindrance.definition: A thing that provides resistance or obstruction to progress; an impediment.
examples: Lack of funding proved to be the biggest hindrance to the research project.
Poor infrastructure remains a major hindrance to economic development in the region.

emolument.definition: A salary, fee, or profit from employment or office; compensation for work.
examples: The position offered generous emoluments including a substantial pension.
The constitutional clause prohibits officials from receiving foreign emoluments.

presidency.definition: The office or term of a president; the period during which a president serves.
examples: Her presidency was marked by economic growth and social reform.
The early months of any presidency set the tone for the entire administration.

armistice.definition: An agreement to stop fighting temporarily; a truce or ceasefire.
examples: The armistice was signed on November 11, 1918, ending World War I.
After months of bitter conflict, both sides agreed to an armistice.

limpid.definition: Clear, transparent, and calm; easily understood.
examples: The limpid waters of the mountain lake revealed every stone on the bottom.
Her limpid prose style made even complex philosophical ideas accessible to general readers.

fatality.definition: A death resulting from an accident, disaster, or act of violence; the quality of being fatal.
examples: The highway crash resulted in three fatalities and several serious injuries.
Improved safety regulations have dramatically reduced workplace fatalities.

absolutism.definition: A political system in which a ruler holds unrestricted power; the practice of holding principles as absolute and non-negotiable.
examples: The French Revolution was a direct response to centuries of royal absolutism.
Moral absolutism holds that certain actions are always wrong regardless of context.

clarity.definition: The quality of being clear, pure, and easy to understand; freedom from ambiguity.
examples: The clarity of her writing made the technical manual easy for anyone to follow.
After weeks of confusion, a moment of clarity finally revealed the path forward.
clarity.metaphor: Clarity of purpose is a lighthouse beam cutting through the fog of indecision.

complexity.definition: The state of having many interrelated parts or aspects; intricacy.
examples: The sheer complexity of the tax code overwhelms even experienced accountants.
She relished the complexity of the problem, seeing it as an intellectual challenge.

addiction.definition: A compulsive dependence on a substance or behavior despite harmful consequences.
examples: His addiction to painkillers began after a routine surgery.
Social media addiction is increasingly recognized as a public health concern.

accede.definition: To agree to a demand or request; to assume an office or position of authority.
examples: After prolonged negotiations, the company finally acceded to the workers' demands.
When the king died, his eldest son acceded to the throne.

despise.definition: To feel strong contempt or disdain for; to regard as beneath consideration.
examples: She despised dishonesty in any form and would not tolerate it in her team.
He despised the hypocrisy of those who preached charity but practiced greed.

deftly.definition: In a skillful, clever, and quick manner; with nimble precision.
examples: The chef deftly filleted the fish with a few swift strokes of the knife.
She deftly navigated the awkward conversation, steering it to safer ground.

indistinct.definition: Not clear or sharply defined; vague and hard to make out.
examples: The indistinct outline of a figure appeared through the fog.
His memories of that night had grown indistinct with the passage of time.

circumscribe.definition: To restrict or confine within limits; to define the boundaries of.
examples: The new regulations circumscribed the powers of the intelligence agencies.
Their freedom was circumscribed by tradition and social expectation.

tenuous.definition: Very weak or slight; thin and insubstantial; lacking a sound basis.
examples: The connection between the two events was tenuous at best.
Their tenuous grip on power was shaken by the latest scandal.
tenuous.metaphor: Their friendship was tenuous, a thread that could snap at the slightest tug.

restless.definition: Unable to rest or relax; constantly seeking change or movement.
examples: A restless energy drove him to start three businesses before the age of thirty.
She spent a restless night, tossing and turning with anxious thoughts.

permanency.definition: The state or quality of lasting indefinitely; enduring stability.
examples: Nothing in life has the permanency we sometimes wish for.
The permanency of the settlement gave the refugees a sense of security at last.

censorship.definition: The suppression or restriction of speech, public communication, or information deemed objectionable.
examples: Government censorship of the press undermines the foundation of democracy.
The debate over internet censorship continues to divide policymakers worldwide.

potentate.definition: A ruler or person who possesses great power and authority; a monarch or sovereign.
examples: The potentate ruled his kingdom with an iron fist for over forty years.
Ancient potentates built grand monuments to immortalize their reigns.

disillusion.definition: To free from false beliefs or unrealistic expectations; to disappoint by revealing the truth.
examples: Traveling to the supposedly perfect city only disillusioned her about the travel brochures.
The scandal disillusioned an entire generation of voters.

verbiage.definition: An excess of words; unnecessarily wordy or verbose language.
examples: The contract was buried under so much legal verbiage that no one could understand it.
Cut the verbiage and tell me what you actually mean.

inopportune.definition: Occurring at an inconvenient or inappropriate time; badly timed.
examples: His inopportune phone call interrupted the most important moment of the presentation.
The rain came at an inopportune moment, just as the outdoor ceremony was about to begin.

entangle.definition: To cause to become twisted together or caught in; to involve in complicated or compromising circumstances.
examples: The fishing line became hopelessly entangled in the underwater weeds.
She warned him not to get entangled in office politics.

squelch.definition: To suppress or silence forcefully; to crush or squash.
examples: The manager squelched the rumor before it could spread through the office.
The government attempted to squelch dissent by shutting down opposition newspapers.

opiate.definition: A drug derived from opium that relieves pain and induces sleep; anything that dulls the senses or awareness.
examples: The opioid crisis has highlighted the dangers of overprescribing opiates.
Television has been called the opiate of the masses.

farce.definition: A comic dramatic work using highly improbable situations; an absurd or ridiculous event or situation.
examples: The play was a brilliantly staged farce full of mistaken identities and slamming doors.
The trial was widely regarded as a farce, with the verdict decided before it even began.

vitality.definition: The state of being strong, active, and full of energy; the power that gives life.
examples: Despite her age, she possessed a remarkable vitality that energized everyone around her.
The vitality of the local arts scene attracted creative people from across the region.

condolence.definition: An expression of sympathy and sorrow, especially following a death.
examples: Friends and colleagues sent letters of condolence to the bereaved family.
She offered her sincere condolences and a warm embrace.

endanger.definition: To put at risk of harm, injury, or loss; to threaten.
examples: Reckless driving endangers not only the driver but everyone on the road.
Deforestation continues to endanger countless species around the world.

incumbency.definition: The holding of an office or position; the period during which someone holds office.
examples: During his incumbency, the mayor oversaw the construction of three new parks.
The advantage of incumbency makes it difficult for challengers to win elections.

skyrocket.definition: To increase rapidly and dramatically; to shoot up like a rocket.
examples: Housing prices have skyrocketed in the past decade, pricing out many first-time buyers.
The singer's popularity skyrocketed after her performance went viral.

incredulous.definition: Unwilling or unable to believe something; expressing disbelief.
examples: She gave him an incredulous look when he claimed to have run a four-minute mile.
The audience was incredulous when the magician seemed to levitate off the stage.

requiem.definition: A musical composition or ceremony honoring the dead; a lament for the departed.
examples: Mozart's Requiem remains one of the most powerful works in classical music.
The documentary served as a requiem for a vanishing way of life.
requiem.metaphor: The autumn leaves fell in a silent requiem for the dying summer.

fearless.definition: Without fear; brave and bold in the face of danger or difficulty.
examples: The fearless journalist continued reporting from the war zone despite the risks.
Her fearless approach to innovation disrupted an entire industry.

maxim.definition: A short, pithy statement expressing a general truth or rule of conduct.
examples: The old maxim "measure twice, cut once" is excellent advice for any project.
She lived by the maxim that honesty is the best policy.

deterrent.definition: Something that discourages or prevents a particular action, especially by arousing fear of consequences.
examples: Nuclear weapons were designed to serve as a deterrent against large-scale war.
The heavy fines act as a deterrent to illegal dumping.

contiguous.definition: Sharing a common border; touching or connected throughout an unbroken sequence.
examples: The contiguous United States refers to the 48 states that share borders with each other.
The two properties are contiguous, separated only by a low stone wall.

imperceptible.definition: So slight, gradual, or subtle as to be almost impossible to perceive.
examples: The change in her expression was almost imperceptible, but he noticed it.
The ship moved at an imperceptible speed through the calm waters.

productivity.definition: The effectiveness of productive effort, measured in terms of output per unit of input.
examples: Remote work has actually increased productivity for many knowledge workers.
The new software tools dramatically improved the team's productivity.

nudge.definition: To push gently; to prod someone into action or a particular direction through subtle encouragement.
examples: She nudged him under the table to stop him from saying anything embarrassing.
The policy was designed to nudge consumers toward healthier food choices.

parlance.definition: A particular way of speaking or using words, especially in a specific group or profession.
examples: In legal parlance, the term "tort" refers to a wrongful act leading to civil liability.
What Silicon Valley calls "disruption" is, in common parlance, simply doing things differently.

treatise.definition: A formal and systematic written work dealing with a subject in depth.
examples: Darwin's treatise on evolution fundamentally changed how we understand life on Earth.
She published a comprehensive treatise on international trade law.

simultaneous.definition: Occurring, operating, or done at the same time.
examples: The simultaneous launch of the product in twelve countries was a logistical triumph.
She managed the simultaneous demands of career, family, and graduate school with grace.

atrocious.definition: Horrifyingly wicked or cruel; also, of extremely poor quality.
examples: The atrocious conditions in the factory sparked a national outcry for reform.
The food at the airport restaurant was absolutely atrocious.

pinnacle.definition: The highest point of achievement, development, or fame; the peak.
examples: Winning the Nobel Prize represented the pinnacle of her scientific career.
The empire reached its pinnacle in the third century before beginning its slow decline.
pinnacle.metaphor: She stood at the pinnacle of her powers, looking out over a landscape of possibility.

patriotism.definition: Devoted love, support, and defense of one's country; national loyalty.
examples: True patriotism sometimes means having the courage to criticize your own government.
The holiday celebrations stirred feelings of patriotism across the nation.

relent.definition: To become less severe or intense; to give in after initially refusing.
examples: The storm showed no sign of relenting as night fell.
After hours of persuasion, her father finally relented and let her go to the concert.

deprecate.definition: To express disapproval of; to belittle or speak modestly about oneself (self-deprecating).
examples: She deprecated the idea of spending more money on a problem that needed creative thinking.
His self-deprecating humor made him instantly likable.

sentience.definition: The capacity to feel, perceive, or experience subjectively; conscious awareness.
examples: The question of animal sentience has profound implications for how we treat other species.
As artificial intelligence advances, debates about machine sentience intensify.

invincibility.definition: The quality of being too powerful to be defeated or overcome.
examples: The team's aura of invincibility crumbled after their first loss of the season.
Youth often carries with it a dangerous sense of invincibility.

fallacious.definition: Based on a mistaken belief or faulty reasoning; misleading.
examples: The argument, though popular, was entirely fallacious.
Fallacious claims about the product led to a massive recall and lawsuit.

contradict.definition: To assert the opposite of a statement; to be inconsistent with.
examples: The new evidence seemed to contradict the prosecution's entire theory.
His actions contradicted his carefully crafted public image.

admonition.definition: A firm warning or reprimand; earnest counsel against fault or oversight.
examples: The judge issued a stern admonition to the witness about the consequences of perjury.
Despite her mother's admonitions, she went ahead with the risky investment.

repast.definition: A meal, especially a formal or elaborate one.
examples: The guests sat down to a sumptuous repast of roasted lamb and seasonal vegetables.
After the long hike, even a simple repast of bread and cheese tasted extraordinary.

criterion.definition: A standard or principle by which something is judged or decided.
examples: Academic performance was only one criterion used in the admissions process.
The key criterion for success in this role is the ability to work under pressure.
She read the report in its entirety before making her decision.
The beauty of the landscape could only be appreciated in its entirety from the hilltop.

partiality.definition: Unfair bias in favor of one thing or person; a particular fondness or liking.
examples: The referee was accused of showing partiality toward the home team.
She had a well-known partiality for dark chocolate and strong coffee.

assiduous.definition: Showing great care, attention, and persistent effort; diligent.
examples: Her assiduous research over many years produced groundbreaking results.
The assiduous student spent every evening in the library preparing for exams.

improvise.definition: To create or perform spontaneously without preparation; to make do with available resources.
examples: When the projector failed, she improvised by drawing diagrams on the whiteboard.
Jazz musicians must be able to improvise brilliantly in real time.

daunt.definition: To make someone feel intimidated or discouraged; to dishearten.
examples: The sheer scale of the project daunted even the most experienced engineers.
She refused to be daunted by the criticism and pressed forward with her plans.

magnate.definition: A wealthy and influential person, especially in business or industry.
examples: The media magnate controlled newspapers and television stations across three continents.
Real estate magnates reshaped the skyline of the city over the course of a decade.

sensitivity.definition: The quality of being sensitive; awareness of and responsiveness to feelings, conditions, or subtleties.
examples: The topic requires great sensitivity, given the personal nature of the experiences involved.
His sensitivity to criticism sometimes held him back from sharing his best ideas.

omnivorous.definition: Feeding on both plants and animals; figuratively, eager to consume all kinds of information or experience.
examples: Bears are omnivorous, eating everything from berries to salmon.
She was an omnivorous reader, devouring everything from detective novels to philosophy.

theorize.definition: To form a theory or theories about something; to speculate based on available evidence.
examples: Scientists theorize that the universe began with a massive expansion known as the Big Bang.
It is dangerous to theorize before you have all the facts.

nimbus.definition: A luminous cloud or halo surrounding a supernatural being or saint; also, a large gray rain cloud.
examples: In medieval paintings, saints are often depicted with a golden nimbus around their heads.
Dark nimbus clouds gathered on the horizon, promising a heavy downpour.
nimbus.metaphor: A nimbus of authority surrounded her wherever she went.

dislodge.definition: To remove from an established or fixed position; to force out.
examples: The earthquake dislodged boulders that tumbled down the mountainside.
No amount of argument could dislodge him from his firmly held beliefs.

dissect.definition: To cut apart for examination; to analyze in minute detail.
examples: Biology students learn to dissect specimens to understand anatomy.
The critics dissected every line of the poem, finding layers of hidden meaning.

tenure.definition: The holding of an office or position; a period of holding a position; guaranteed permanent employment.
examples: During her tenure as CEO, the company tripled in value.
The professor was granted tenure after publishing several influential papers.

impostor.definition: A person who pretends to be someone else in order to deceive others.
examples: The impostor posed as a doctor for months before being exposed.
Impostor syndrome makes high achievers feel like frauds despite their genuine accomplishments.

fabulous.definition: Extraordinarily great or impressive; also, relating to fable or legend.
examples: The hotel offered fabulous views of the valley from every room.
The explorer returned with fabulous tales of lost cities and hidden treasures.

millennial.definition: Relating to a millennium or a thousand-year period; relating to the generation born roughly between 1981 and 1996.
examples: Millennial consumers tend to prioritize experiences over material possessions.
The cathedral has stood for nearly a millennial span, surviving wars and revolutions.

cordiality.definition: Warm and sincere friendliness; heartfelt goodwill.
examples: The cordiality of our hosts made the visit genuinely enjoyable.
Beneath the surface cordiality, there was an unmistakable tension between the two rivals.

informative.definition: Providing useful or interesting information; educational.
examples: The documentary was both informative and deeply moving.
Her informative blog post on personal finance went viral overnight.

impotence.definition: The inability to take effective action; helplessness or powerlessness.
examples: The committee expressed frustration at its own impotence to enforce the regulations.
Political impotence in the face of the crisis led to widespread public anger.

revelry.definition: Lively and noisy celebration or merrymaking.
examples: The sounds of revelry from the street carnival could be heard blocks away.
After the revelry of New Year's Eve, the city fell into a quiet morning haze.

affidavit.definition: A written statement confirmed by oath, used as evidence in legal proceedings.
examples: The witness signed an affidavit confirming she had seen the defendant at the scene.
The lawyer submitted an affidavit supporting the motion for an emergency injunction.

selfless.definition: Concerned more with the needs of others than with one's own; unselfish.
examples: Her selfless dedication to the cause inspired everyone who worked alongside her.
The firefighter's selfless act of bravery saved three children from the burning building.

exemplify.definition: To serve as a typical example of; to illustrate by being an instance of.
examples: Her career exemplifies what can be achieved through hard work and perseverance.
The building exemplifies the best of Art Deco architecture.

millionaire.definition: A person whose wealth amounts to at least one million units of currency.
examples: She became a self-made millionaire before the age of thirty.
The neighborhood was home to several millionaires who lived surprisingly modest lives.

symbolism.definition: The use of symbols to represent ideas or qualities; symbolic meaning attached to objects or events.
examples: The symbolism of the dove as a representation of peace is recognized worldwide.
Students analyzed the rich symbolism woven throughout the novel.

wayward.definition: Difficult to control or predict; turning away from what is expected; willfully errant.
examples: The wayward child refused to follow any rules, much to the frustration of her teachers.
A wayward gust of wind scattered the papers across the courtyard.

fraternity.definition: A group of people sharing common interests or profession; brotherhood; also, a male student organization.
examples: There is a strong sense of fraternity among firefighters that extends beyond the job.
He pledged a fraternity during his freshman year at college.

matchless.definition: So good that no one or nothing can equal it; unrivaled.
examples: Her matchless talent for negotiation made her invaluable to the diplomatic team.
The sunset over the canyon was a matchless display of nature's beauty.

convincingly.definition: In a manner that causes someone to believe or agree; persuasively.
examples: She argued her case so convincingly that the panel reversed its initial decision.
The actor convincingly portrayed a character far removed from his own personality.

lagoon.definition: A shallow body of water separated from the sea by a barrier of sand or coral.
examples: The turquoise lagoon was so clear you could see the fish swimming near the bottom.
The village was built on stilts over a tranquil lagoon.

boycott.definition: To withdraw from commercial or social relations with a person, organization, or country as a protest.
examples: Consumers organized a boycott of the company after its environmental violations were exposed.
The athletes threatened to boycott the games in protest of human rights abuses.

perplexity.definition: A state of being puzzled, confused, or bewildered.
examples: A look of utter perplexity crossed his face as he tried to solve the riddle.
The contradictory evidence left the investigators in a state of perplexity.

gist.definition: The main point or essence of a matter; the substance of an argument or speech.
examples: I didn't read the entire report, but I got the gist of it from the executive summary.
The gist of her argument was that education reform requires more than just funding.

sympathetic.definition: Feeling or showing sympathy; inclined to approve or support.
examples: The counselor was sympathetic but firm in her advice.
He found a sympathetic audience among those who had experienced similar hardships.

uproarious.definition: Extremely funny; causing loud laughter; also, characterized by noisy commotion.
examples: His uproarious stand-up routine had the entire audience in tears of laughter.
The uproarious debate in parliament made headlines across the country.

hypochondriac.definition: A person who is excessively worried about having a serious illness despite having no or mild symptoms.
examples: He was a self-confessed hypochondriac who interpreted every headache as a sign of something terrible.
The internet has turned many people into hypochondriacs, googling every minor symptom.

invincible.definition: Too powerful to be defeated or overcome; unconquerable.
examples: The team seemed invincible during their record-breaking winning streak.
No army is truly invincible, as history has repeatedly demonstrated.
invincible.metaphor: With knowledge as her shield, she felt invincible against the world's uncertainties.

inflation.definition: A general increase in prices and fall in the purchasing value of money over time.
