examples: It would be premature to celebrate before all the votes have been counted.
The premature announcement caused confusion among employees and investors alike.

cherish.definition: To hold dear; to feel and show great love, care, and affection for someone or something.
examples: She cherished the handwritten letters her grandmother had left behind.
A wise person cherishes friendships that stand the test of time.
cherish.metaphor: He cherished that memory like a flame cupped against the wind.

subsidize.definition: To support financially; to provide money to help pay for something, often from public funds.
examples: The government subsidized renewable energy projects to encourage green development.
Without being subsidized, many rural bus routes would have been discontinued.

cartel.definition: An association of companies or organizations formed to control prices and limit competition.
examples: The oil cartel manipulated supply to keep global prices artificially high.
Authorities dismantled a drug cartel that had operated across three countries.

compatibility.definition: The ability of things or people to exist or work together without conflict.
examples: The couple quickly discovered their compatibility extended beyond shared hobbies.
Software compatibility is a major concern when upgrading enterprise systems.

evasion.definition: The act of avoiding or escaping something, especially by cleverness or deception.
examples: Tax evasion carries severe penalties, including imprisonment.
Her evasion of the direct question only heightened suspicion.

apostasy.definition: The abandonment or renunciation of a religious faith, political belief, or set of principles.
examples: His apostasy from the party shocked those who had considered him a true believer.
In some societies, apostasy from the dominant religion can have severe consequences.

blissful.definition: Extremely happy; full of joy and contentment.
examples: They spent a blissful week in the countryside, far from the demands of work.
She looked back on her childhood with a blissful sense of nostalgia.

surmount.definition: To overcome a difficulty or obstacle; to prevail over; also, to be on top of.
examples: With determination, she surmounted every challenge that stood in her way.
The tower was surmounted by a golden dome visible for miles.

anonymity.definition: The condition of being anonymous or unknown; lack of identification.
examples: The whistleblower insisted on anonymity to protect her family from retaliation.
Social media gives people a sense of anonymity that can lead to reckless behavior.
anonymity.metaphor: Anonymity is a cloak that emboldens the timid and shelters the reckless.

catapult.definition: To hurl or launch with great force; to suddenly propel into a new situation or prominence.
examples: The viral video catapulted the unknown singer to international fame overnight.
The scandal catapulted the issue of corporate ethics into the public spotlight.

eject.definition: To force or throw someone or something out; to expel.
examples: The bouncer ejected the unruly patron from the nightclub.
The pilot was forced to eject from the aircraft moments before it crashed.

primeval.definition: Belonging to the earliest ages; ancient and unspoiled; primitive.
examples: The hikers wandered through a primeval forest untouched by human development.
There was something primeval about the thunderstorm, a reminder of forces beyond human control.

prediction.definition: A statement about what will happen in the future; a forecast or prophecy.
examples: His prediction that the market would crash proved eerily accurate.
Weather predictions have become far more reliable thanks to advanced modeling technology.

festivity.definition: Joyful celebration; the activities and atmosphere of a festival or party.
examples: The streets were alive with festivity during the annual harvest celebration.
Despite the challenges of the past year, the holiday festivity lifted everyone's spirits.

disband.definition: To break up or dissolve an organized group, such as a team, army, or committee.
examples: The committee voted to disband after completing its final report.
The rebel forces agreed to disband as part of the peace agreement.

erroneous.definition: Wrong; incorrect; based on an error in fact or reasoning.
examples: The article was retracted after several erroneous claims were discovered.
His erroneous assumption that the project was on track led to a costly delay.

resiliency.definition: The ability to recover quickly from difficulties; toughness and adaptability.
examples: The resiliency of the community after the flood was truly inspiring.
Emotional resiliency is one of the most important skills a person can develop.
resiliency.metaphor: Resiliency is the spring inside us that pushes back against the weight of hardship.

foretaste.definition: A sample or suggestion of something that is to come; an advance experience.
examples: The warm weekend in February was a welcome foretaste of spring.
The opening chapter gave readers a tantalizing foretaste of the mystery to come.

intuition.definition: The ability to understand something instinctively, without conscious reasoning; a gut feeling.
examples: Her intuition told her something was wrong, even though she could not explain it.
Experienced doctors often rely on intuition as much as test results when making diagnoses.
intuition.metaphor: Intuition is the compass that points us forward when logic reaches its limits.

rapidity.definition: Great speed or swiftness; the quality of happening or moving very quickly.
examples: The rapidity of technological change in the last decade has been staggering.
She typed with a rapidity that made her colleagues shake their heads in disbelief.

dehydrate.definition: To remove water or moisture from something; to become dried out.
examples: Hikers should drink plenty of water to avoid becoming dehydrated in the heat.
The chef dehydrated the fruit slices to create a crispy, flavorful garnish.

quibble.definition: A minor objection or criticism about a trivial matter; a petty argument.
examples: My only quibble with the restaurant is that the service was a bit slow.
Let us not quibble over minor details when there are bigger issues to address.

guilt.definition: The state of having committed a wrongful act; also, the feeling of remorse or responsibility for a wrong.
examples: The jury found the defendant guilty beyond a reasonable doubt.
She was consumed by guilt after realizing how her words had hurt her friend.
guilt.metaphor: Guilt is a shadow that follows you everywhere, growing longer as the day wears on.

discordance.definition: A lack of agreement or harmony; conflict or inconsistency.
examples: The discordance between his public statements and private actions was troubling.
There was a noticeable discordance among the team members about the project direction.

resemble.definition: To look like or be similar to someone or something.
examples: The child strongly resembled her grandmother at the same age.
The new building was designed to resemble a ship sailing into the harbor.

wizardry.definition: Great skill or cleverness, especially in a particular field; seemingly magical ability.
examples: The chef's culinary wizardry turned simple ingredients into extraordinary dishes.
Her technical wizardry allowed the small startup to compete with industry giants.

madden.definition: To make someone extremely angry, frustrated, or insane.
examples: The constant noise from the construction site was enough to madden anyone.
It maddened him to watch talented people waste their potential.

unbecoming.definition: Not flattering or appropriate; unsuitable; improper for the person or occasion.
examples: Her rude behavior at the ceremony was unbecoming of someone in her position.
The ill-fitting suit was unbecoming and did little to help his confidence.

oasis.definition: A fertile spot in a desert where water is found; figuratively, a peaceful refuge in the midst of difficulty.
examples: After days of travel, the caravan finally reached a lush oasis.
The quiet park was an oasis of calm in the middle of the bustling city.
oasis.metaphor: Their friendship was an oasis in the desert of her loneliness.

sly.definition: Cunning and deceitful; showing a secretive, knowing cleverness.
examples: A sly smile crossed his face as he realized his plan was working perfectly.
The fox is often portrayed as a sly creature in folklore and fables.

simian.definition: Resembling or relating to apes or monkeys.
examples: The comedian's simian gestures had the audience howling with laughter.
Researchers studied the simian behavior patterns for clues about human evolution.

dupe.definition: To deceive or trick someone into believing or doing something; also, a person who is easily deceived.
examples: The con artist duped dozens of investors out of their life savings.
She refused to be a dupe for anyone's hidden agenda.

anthropomorphism.definition: The attribution of human characteristics, emotions, or behavior to non-human entities, such as animals or objects.
examples: The tendency toward anthropomorphism is why we describe storms as angry and rivers as lazy.
Children's literature is full of anthropomorphism, with talking animals and thinking toys.

admissible.definition: Acceptable or valid, especially as evidence in a court of law; allowable.
examples: The judge ruled that the recording was admissible as evidence.
Only admissible forms of identification will be accepted at the border.

inborn.definition: Existing from birth; natural; innate rather than acquired.
examples: She had an inborn talent for music that became evident before she could walk.
Some scientists believe that a sense of fairness is inborn in humans.

calmness.definition: The state of being peaceful, quiet, and free from agitation or strong emotion.
examples: Her calmness in the face of danger reassured everyone around her.
The calmness of the lake at dawn made it a perfect place for meditation.
calmness.metaphor: His calmness was an anchor that steadied everyone during the storm.

trajectory.definition: The path followed by a moving object; figuratively, the direction or course of development.
examples: The trajectory of the comet was tracked by astronomers around the world.
Her career trajectory took her from entry-level analyst to CEO in just fifteen years.

equitable.definition: Fair and impartial; just and reasonable in the way people are treated.
examples: The mediator worked to find an equitable solution that satisfied both parties.
Access to quality education should be equitable regardless of socioeconomic background.

verdant.definition: Green with grass or other rich vegetation; lush and flourishing.
examples: The verdant hillsides of Ireland are among the most beautiful landscapes in Europe.
After weeks of rain, the once barren field became verdant and alive.
verdant.metaphor: Her imagination was verdant, always producing new ideas in abundance.

maestro.definition: A master or expert in an art, especially a distinguished conductor or musician.
examples: The maestro lifted his baton, and the entire orchestra fell silent with anticipation.
She was a maestro in the kitchen, transforming ordinary ingredients into culinary masterpieces.

embargo.definition: An official ban on trade or commerce with a particular country; any restriction or prohibition.
examples: The international embargo on arms sales put pressure on the warring nation.
The publisher placed an embargo on the book, preventing any reviews before the release date.

vacuous.definition: Having or showing a lack of thought or intelligence; empty; mindless.
examples: His vacuous grin suggested he had not understood a word of the conversation.
The film received harsh reviews for its vacuous plot and shallow characters.

tragic.definition: Causing or characterized by extreme sadness, suffering, or disaster; devastatingly unfortunate.
examples: The tragic accident claimed the lives of three young passengers.
Despite his tragic childhood, he grew up to be a compassionate and successful leader.

sanctimonious.definition: Making a show of being morally superior to others; hypocritically pious or righteous.
examples: His sanctimonious lectures about healthy eating annoyed everyone at the dinner table.
The politician's sanctimonious speeches rang hollow once his private behavior came to light.

landmark.definition: A prominent or important feature of an area; a significant event, discovery, or achievement.
examples: The old clock tower is the most recognizable landmark in the city.
The Supreme Court ruling was a landmark decision in the fight for civil rights.

inflammatory.definition: Intended to arouse strong feelings of anger or indignation; provocative and incendiary.
examples: The speaker's inflammatory rhetoric nearly incited a riot among the crowd.
Social media posts with inflammatory content tend to spread faster than factual ones.

verbosity.definition: The use of more words than necessary; excessive wordiness.
examples: The editor ruthlessly cut the verbosity from the manuscript, making it half its original length.
His verbosity in meetings tested everyone's patience.

embryonic.definition: In an early stage of development; just beginning; rudimentary.
examples: The project was still in its embryonic phase when funding was suddenly cut.
Her embryonic idea eventually grew into a billion-dollar enterprise.

debut.definition: A person's first public appearance or performance; the first time something is introduced.
examples: The young actress made her Broadway debut to rave reviews.
The company will debut its latest smartphone at the technology conference next month.

reverie.definition: A state of being pleasantly lost in one's thoughts; a daydream.
examples: She was lost in reverie, staring out the window at the falling snow.
The sound of the doorbell jolted him out of his afternoon reverie.
reverie.metaphor: His mind drifted into a reverie, a quiet river of memory flowing through the present.

inauspicious.definition: Not conducive to success; showing signs of a bad outcome; unpromising.
examples: The project had an inauspicious beginning, plagued by budget cuts and delays.
Despite the inauspicious weather forecast, the outdoor concert went ahead as planned.

inevitable.definition: Certain to happen; unavoidable; impossible to prevent.
examples: Change is inevitable, but growth is optional.
As the scandal widened, his resignation became inevitable.
inevitable.metaphor: Aging is the inevitable tide that reshapes every shore.

paroxysm.definition: A sudden outburst of emotion or action; a violent attack or fit.
examples: She burst into a paroxysm of laughter that she could not control.
The news triggered a paroxysm of rage that startled everyone in the room.

intractability.definition: The quality of being difficult to manage, control, or solve; stubbornness.
examples: The intractability of the conflict frustrated diplomats on both sides.
The intractability of the disease made it one of the greatest challenges in modern medicine.

humidity.definition: The amount of moisture in the air; dampness.
examples: The humidity in the tropical region made the heat feel almost unbearable.
High humidity can cause mold growth in poorly ventilated buildings.

successor.definition: A person or thing that follows and takes the place of another.
examples: The CEO announced her retirement and named her successor effective immediately.
The new model is a worthy successor to the bestselling original.

insatiable.definition: Impossible to satisfy; always wanting more.
examples: Her insatiable curiosity led her to read three books a week.
The corporation had an insatiable appetite for acquisitions, swallowing smaller companies whole.
insatiable.metaphor: Ambition can be an insatiable fire, consuming everything it touches.

contrition.definition: Deep remorse or guilt for a wrong committed; sincere repentance.
examples: His letter of contrition was heartfelt and convinced the board to give him a second chance.
Without genuine contrition, an apology is just empty words.

mundane.definition: Lacking interest or excitement; dull and ordinary; relating to everyday life rather than the spiritual.
examples: Even the most mundane tasks can become meaningful when done with care.
After years of adventure travel, she found it hard to return to mundane office life.

quatrain.definition: A stanza or poem consisting of four lines, typically with a specific rhyme scheme.
examples: Shakespeare often concluded his sonnets with a powerful closing quatrain.
The poet crafted each quatrain with meticulous attention to rhythm and sound.

alembic.definition: An apparatus formerly used for distillation; figuratively, anything that refines or transforms.
examples: The alchemists used an alembic in their attempts to transmute base metals into gold.
Great literature passes raw human experience through the alembic of imagination.
alembic.metaphor: Her mind was an alembic that distilled complex problems into elegant solutions.

disingenuous.definition: Not candid or sincere; pretending to know less or be less involved than one really is.
examples: It would be disingenuous to claim the decision was made without political considerations.
His disingenuous surprise at the outcome fooled no one who knew the full story.

shibboleth.definition: A custom, phrase, or belief that distinguishes one group from another; also, an outdated principle still clung to.
examples: Proper pronunciation of certain words served as a shibboleth to identify outsiders.
The old guard clung to shibboleths that had long since lost their relevance.

weighty.definition: Heavy; also, very serious, important, or influential.
examples: The committee was tasked with making several weighty decisions about the company future.
His weighty contributions to the field earned him a Nobel Prize nomination.

abet.definition: To encourage or assist someone in doing something wrong or illegal.
examples: Anyone who aids and abets a fugitive can be charged as an accessory.
The manager was accused of abetting fraud by looking the other way.

shrivel.definition: To wrinkle and shrink, especially from dryness, heat, or age; to wither.
examples: The flowers shriveled in the heat after just a few hours without water.
His confidence shriveled under the relentless criticism of his supervisor.
shrivel.metaphor: Hope can shrivel like a leaf in drought if it is not nurtured with action.

commandeer.definition: To take possession of something for military or official use; to seize for personal purposes.
examples: During the crisis, the military commandeered several civilian vehicles for transport.
She commandeered the conference room for an impromptu brainstorming session.

dais.definition: A low platform for a speaker, lectern, or throne, raised above the surrounding floor.
examples: The president stepped onto the dais and adjusted the microphone.
A single chair sat on the dais at the front of the grand hall.

regale.definition: To entertain or delight with conversation, stories, or good food and drink.
examples: Grandpa regaled us with stories of his adventures during the war.
The host regaled her guests with a feast of local delicacies.

expense.definition: The cost or price paid for something; also, something sacrificed or lost in pursuit of a goal.
examples: The renovation came at considerable expense but was well worth the investment.
He achieved success at the expense of his personal relationships.

darling.definition: A person who is very dear to another; a beloved person; also, a favorite of the public.
examples: The young actress quickly became the darling of the film festival circuit.
She was the darling of the literary world, praised by critics and readers alike.

allusion.definition: An indirect or passing reference to something without explicitly mentioning it.
examples: The novel is filled with allusions to Greek mythology and Renaissance art.
His allusion to her past mistakes was subtle but unmistakable.

morbid.definition: Having an unhealthy interest in disturbing or unpleasant subjects, especially death; diseased or abnormal.
examples: She had a morbid fascination with true crime documentaries.
The therapist helped him overcome his morbid fear of flying.

hodgepodge.definition: A confused mixture; a jumble of dissimilar things thrown together.
examples: The museum exhibit was a hodgepodge of artifacts from different centuries.
Her closet was a hodgepodge of designer clothes and thrift-store finds.

acquisitive.definition: Excessively interested in acquiring money or material things; eager to accumulate possessions.
examples: The acquisitive billionaire added yet another mansion to his collection of properties.
An acquisitive society tends to measure success in material rather than moral terms.

statecraft.definition: The skillful management of state affairs; the art of governing and diplomacy.
examples: Effective statecraft requires balancing national interests with international obligations.
Her memoirs offered a rare glimpse into the statecraft behind the peace negotiations.

legislate.definition: To make or enact laws; to bring something about through legislation.
examples: Congress has the power to legislate on matters of national security.
You cannot legislate morality, but you can create laws that protect basic rights.

unassuming.definition: Modest; not pretentious or arrogant; humble in manner.
examples: Despite her enormous wealth, she remained remarkably unassuming.
The unassuming little restaurant on the corner turned out to serve the best food in town.

attribute.definition: To regard something as being caused by or belonging to someone or something; to credit or assign.
examples: Historians attribute the fall of the empire to a combination of internal corruption and external pressure.
She attributed her success to hard work and the support of her mentors.

odious.definition: Extremely unpleasant; repulsive; arousing hatred or disgust.
examples: The dictator committed odious crimes against his own people.
Racism in all its forms is an odious stain on human history.

hospitable.definition: Friendly and generous in welcoming guests or strangers; also, favorable or conducive.
examples: The family was incredibly hospitable, insisting we stay for dinner.
The island proved hospitable to a wide variety of plant and animal species.

impel.definition: To drive or urge someone to action; to push forward with force.
examples: A sense of justice impelled her to speak out against the corruption.
Curiosity impelled him to open the mysterious package despite the warning.

misread.definition: To read or interpret something incorrectly; to misjudge.
examples: She completely misread the tone of his email and took offense where none was intended.
Investors who misread the market signals lost significant amounts of money.

intrusion.definition: The act of intruding or entering without permission or welcome; an unwanted interference.
examples: She resented the constant intrusion of work emails into her personal life.
The security system detected an intrusion attempt and triggered an immediate lockdown.

spiteful.definition: Showing a desire to hurt, annoy, or offend someone; full of malice.
examples: Her spiteful remarks were designed to undermine her colleague in front of the boss.
Spreading spiteful rumors is a cowardly way to deal with personal grievances.

carnage.definition: The killing of a large number of people; great destruction and bloodshed.
examples: The battlefield was a scene of utter carnage after the daylong siege.
First responders were shocked by the carnage caused by the highway pileup.
She tackled every new project with vim and determination.
Despite his age, he worked with a vim that put his younger colleagues to shame.

undervalue.definition: To rate or estimate something below its true worth; to fail to appreciate fully.
examples: Many employers undervalue soft skills like communication and empathy.
She realized she had been undervaluing her own contributions to the team.

conscientious.definition: Wishing to do what is right; thorough, careful, and guided by a sense of duty.
examples: She was a conscientious employee who never left work half-done.
His conscientious approach to research earned him the trust of his peers.

excellence.definition: The quality of being outstanding or extremely good; superiority in merit or virtue.
examples: The school has a long tradition of academic excellence.
Pursuing excellence requires both talent and relentless dedication.

trenchant.definition: Vigorous, effective, and sharply articulate; incisively clear and keen.
examples: The editorial offered a trenchant critique of the government policy.
Her trenchant wit made her one of the most quoted columnists in the country.
trenchant.metaphor: His trenchant observations cut through the confusion like a blade through fog.

fragment.definition: A small piece broken off from something larger; an incomplete part.
examples: Archaeologists carefully pieced together fragments of the ancient pottery.
Only fragments of the original manuscript have survived to the present day.

unutterable.definition: Too great, intense, or awful to be expressed in words; indescribable.
examples: She felt an unutterable grief at the loss of her lifelong companion.
The beauty of the sunset left him with an unutterable sense of wonder.

snobbish.definition: Relating to or characteristic of a snob; showing disapproval of people considered to be of a lower social class.
examples: His snobbish attitude toward people who did not attend elite universities alienated many.
The restaurant had a snobbish reputation that kept away ordinary diners.

sylvan.definition: Relating to or characteristic of woods and forests; pleasantly rural or pastoral.
examples: They built their dream home in a sylvan setting surrounded by ancient oaks.
The sylvan landscape of the valley inspired countless painters and poets.

unaffected.definition: Genuine and sincere; free from pretension; also, not influenced or changed.
examples: Despite her fame, she remained unaffected and approachable.
The coastal town was unaffected by the storm that devastated neighboring areas.

implausible.definition: Not seeming reasonable or probable; failing to convince.
examples: The witness offered an implausible explanation that the jury did not believe.
The plot of the movie relied on several implausible coincidences.

concord.definition: Agreement or harmony between people or groups; a state of peaceful coexistence.
examples: The treaty established a lasting concord between the two nations.
Music, at its best, creates a sense of concord that transcends language.

appropriateness.definition: The quality of being suitable, proper, or fitting for a particular situation.
examples: She questioned the appropriateness of wearing jeans to a formal dinner.
The appropriateness of his comments was debated long after the meeting ended.

monarchy.definition: A form of government with a monarch as head of state; a kingdom ruled by a king or queen.
examples: The constitutional monarchy balanced royal tradition with democratic governance.
Several European countries maintain a monarchy alongside their parliamentary systems.

mobilize.definition: To organize and prepare people or resources for action or a particular purpose.
examples: The charity mobilized thousands of volunteers after the hurricane.
Social media can be a powerful tool to mobilize public opinion on important issues.

macrocosm.definition: The whole of a complex structure, especially the world or universe, as contrasted with a small part of it.
examples: The social dynamics of the office were a microcosm of the macrocosm of society.
Understanding the macrocosm of global economics requires studying individual markets first.

ashen.definition: Very pale, as from shock or illness; resembling ashes in color.
examples: Her face turned ashen when she heard the devastating news.
The survivors emerged from the wreckage looking ashen and dazed.

neologism.definition: A newly coined word or expression that has recently entered the language.
examples: The internet age has produced countless neologisms like selfie and binge-watch.
Linguists track neologisms to understand how culture shapes language.

irreverent.definition: Showing a lack of respect for things that are generally taken seriously; humorously disrespectful.
examples: His irreverent humor made even the stuffiest audience members crack a smile.
The comedian was known for her irreverent take on politics and social conventions.

vocation.definition: A strong feeling of suitability for a particular career or occupation; a calling.
examples: Teaching was not just a job for her; it was a vocation she had felt drawn to since childhood.
He discovered his true vocation after years of searching in different fields.

mentor.definition: An experienced person who guides and advises someone less experienced; a trusted counselor.
examples: Every successful person can point to at least one mentor who shaped their journey.
She served as a mentor to dozens of young women entering the tech industry.

daydream.definition: A pleasant series of thoughts that distract attention from the present; a fantasy indulged in while awake.
examples: He spent the entire lecture lost in a daydream about his upcoming vacation.
What begins as a daydream can become a vision, and a vision can become a reality.

unconscionable.definition: Not right or reasonable; shockingly unfair or unjust; beyond what is acceptable.
examples: Charging that amount for a basic necessity is unconscionable.
The company made unconscionable profits while its workers struggled to survive.

wondrous.definition: Inspiring a feeling of wonder or delight; marvelous and extraordinary.
examples: The aurora borealis is one of the most wondrous natural phenomena on Earth.
She described the ancient ruins with a wondrous enthusiasm that was contagious.

specious.definition: Superficially plausible but actually wrong; misleadingly attractive in appearance.
examples: His specious arguments sounded convincing until you examined the evidence.
The advertisement made specious claims about the product health benefits.

vernacular.definition: The everyday language spoken by ordinary people in a particular country or region; informal speech.
examples: The novel was written in the vernacular of the American South.
Scientific findings should be translated into the vernacular so everyone can understand them.

enthrall.definition: To capture the fascinated attention of; to charm or captivate completely.
examples: The magician enthralled the audience with increasingly impossible illusions.
She was enthralled by the documentary and watched it three times in one week.

ratify.definition: To formally approve or confirm, especially by signing or voting; to make officially valid.
examples: The Senate voted to ratify the international climate agreement.
All member states must ratify the treaty before it can take effect.

stratagem.definition: A plan or scheme, especially one used to outwit an opponent or achieve something through cunning.
examples: The general devised a brilliant stratagem that caught the enemy completely off guard.
Her stratagem for winning the negotiation involved making the other side think they were winning.

relinquish.definition: To voluntarily give up or let go of something, especially a right, claim, or possession.
examples: He refused to relinquish control of the company he had built from nothing.
The aging champion finally relinquished the title to a younger competitor.

elasticity.definition: The ability to stretch and return to original shape; flexibility and adaptability.
examples: The elasticity of the material makes it ideal for athletic wear.
The elasticity of her schedule allowed her to accommodate last-minute changes.
elasticity.metaphor: Youth has an elasticity of spirit that bounces back from setbacks older hearts cannot.

incredible.definition: Impossible or very difficult to believe; extraordinarily great or extreme.
examples: The team made an incredible comeback in the final minutes of the game.
The view from the summit was absolutely incredible.

celibacy.definition: The state of abstaining from marriage and sexual relations, often for religious reasons.
examples: Celibacy is a vow taken by priests in many religious traditions.
He chose a period of celibacy to focus entirely on his spiritual practice.

plaque.definition: A flat tablet fixed to a wall as a memorial or tribute; also, a deposit on teeth or in arteries.
examples: A bronze plaque on the building commemorated the famous speech delivered there.
Regular brushing helps prevent the buildup of plaque on your teeth.

snob.definition: A person who believes they are superior to others, especially based on social class, education, or taste.
examples: He was a wine snob who refused to drink anything that cost less than fifty dollars.
Being well-educated does not make someone a snob; arrogance does.

scintilla.definition: A tiny trace or spark of a quality or feeling; the smallest possible amount.
examples: There was not a scintilla of doubt in her mind about what she had to do.
The prosecution failed to produce a scintilla of evidence connecting the suspect to the crime.

dusk.definition: The darker stage of twilight; the time of day just before nightfall.
examples: They sat on the porch watching the sky turn shades of purple at dusk.
The streetlights flickered on as dusk settled over the city.
dusk.metaphor: His career was entering its dusk, the brilliant years giving way to quiet reflection.

harangue.definition: A lengthy and aggressive speech or lecture; a forceful verbal attack.
examples: The coach delivered a harangue about discipline that lasted twenty minutes.
She was subjected to a harangue from an angry customer over a minor billing error.

succumb.definition: To give in to pressure, temptation, or an overwhelming force; to die from an illness or injury.
examples: After hours of negotiation, he finally succumbed to their demands.
Many soldiers succumbed to disease before they ever saw battle.

flout.definition: To openly disregard a rule, law, or convention; to show contempt for.
examples: The company routinely flouted environmental regulations to cut costs.
She flouted tradition by wearing a bright red dress to the formal event.

strenuous.definition: Requiring or involving great effort or energy; vigorous and demanding.
examples: The strenuous hike to the summit took six hours and left everyone exhausted.
She made strenuous efforts to meet the deadline despite the setbacks.

nonconformity.definition: Failure or refusal to conform to established customs, rules, or standards.
examples: His nonconformity in matters of dress and behavior made him stand out at the firm.
The history of progress is largely a history of nonconformity.

exult.definition: To feel or show triumphant joy; to rejoice greatly.
examples: The fans exulted when their team scored the winning goal in overtime.
She could not help but exult in her long-awaited victory.

notoriety.definition: The state of being famous or well-known, typically for something negative or disreputable.
examples: The scandal brought the politician unwanted notoriety overnight.
The restaurant gained notoriety for its outrageous prices rather than its food.

embed.definition: To fix firmly and deeply in a surrounding mass; to implant or incorporate into something.
examples: The journalist was embedded with the military unit for three months.
These cultural values are deeply embedded in the fabric of the community.

propitious.definition: Indicating a good chance of success; favorable; auspicious.
examples: The clear skies and calm waters made for propitious sailing conditions.
She waited for a propitious moment to broach the sensitive topic.

avail.definition: To be of use or advantage; to help; also used in the phrase "to no avail," meaning without success.
examples: He tried to fix the engine, but his efforts were to no avail.
The organization availed itself of every opportunity to promote its mission.

talisman.definition: An object thought to have magical powers and bring good luck; a charm.
examples: She wore her grandmother's ring as a talisman against misfortune.
The old coin became his talisman, carried in his pocket for every important meeting.
talisman.metaphor: Her unwavering optimism was a talisman that warded off despair.

denigrate.definition: To criticize unfairly; to disparage or belittle the reputation of someone or something.
examples: It is unprofessional to denigrate a colleague in front of clients.
The campaign chose to denigrate its opponents rather than debate the issues.

wile.definition: A trick or stratagem intended to deceive or ensnare; cunning or craftiness.
examples: The fox is famous in folklore for its wiles and clever escapes.
She used her considerable wiles to negotiate a better deal.

arcanum.definition: A deep secret or mystery; specialized knowledge accessible only to the initiated.
examples: The arcanum of the ancient order was passed down through generations of initiates.
He studied the arcana of medieval alchemy with scholarly devotion.

narrate.definition: To give a spoken or written account of events; to tell a story.
examples: The documentary was narrated by a well-known actor with a commanding voice.
She narrated the events of the evening with vivid detail and dry humor.

reinstate.definition: To restore someone or something to a former position, condition, or right.
examples: The court ordered that the wrongfully terminated employee be reinstated with back pay.
After the investigation cleared him, his security clearance was reinstated.

nationalism.definition: Strong identification with and devotion to one's own nation, sometimes to the exclusion or detriment of others.
examples: Rising nationalism complicated efforts to form a unified trade agreement.
Healthy patriotism enriches a country, but extreme nationalism can divide it.

spotlight.definition: A strong beam of light focused on a particular area; intense public attention.
examples: The scandal thrust the previously obscure company into the spotlight.
She had always preferred working behind the scenes rather than standing in the spotlight.

unreserved.definition: Without reservations or restraint; complete and open; frank.
examples: He received unreserved praise from the critics for his latest performance.
Her unreserved honesty could be startling, but it was always appreciated.

slogan.definition: A short, memorable phrase used in advertising or to express a political or social ideal.
examples: The campaign's slogan became a rallying cry for an entire generation.
A great slogan can make a brand instantly recognizable around the world.

ulterior.definition: Existing beyond what is obvious or admitted; hidden; especially of motives that are secretly self-serving.
examples: She suspected he had ulterior motives for offering to help with the project.
His seemingly generous proposal masked an ulterior agenda.

incriminate.definition: To make someone appear guilty of a crime or wrongdoing; to provide evidence of guilt.
examples: The recovered emails incriminated several senior executives in the fraud scheme.
He refused to answer questions that might incriminate him.

ascetic.definition: Characterized by severe self-discipline and abstention from all forms of indulgence; austere.
examples: The monk lived an ascetic life, owning nothing more than the clothes on his back.
Her ascetic approach to writing meant eliminating every unnecessary word.

goad.definition: To provoke or annoy someone so as to stimulate action or a reaction; to prod.
examples: His rivals goaded him into making a rash decision he would later regret.
The editorial was designed to goad the government into taking action on climate change.

amplification.definition: The process of increasing the volume, size, or scope of something; elaboration or expansion.
examples: The amplification of the sound made it possible to hear the speaker from across the field.
Her essay was a compelling amplification of the themes introduced in her earlier work.

purification.definition: The process of removing impurities or unwanted elements; cleansing.
examples: Water purification systems are essential in areas without access to clean drinking water.
The ritual of purification was central to the spiritual practices of the community.

sluggish.definition: Slow-moving; lacking energy or alertness; inactive.
examples: The economy remained sluggish despite several rounds of stimulus spending.
She felt sluggish all morning after staying up too late the night before.

veneer.definition: A thin decorative covering of wood; figuratively, an outward appearance that conceals the true nature.
examples: The furniture was made of cheap wood covered with an oak veneer.
Beneath his veneer of politeness lay a deeply calculating personality.
veneer.metaphor: Civilization is sometimes just a veneer, stripped away by fear or desperation.

sheepish.definition: Showing embarrassment from shame or a lack of self-confidence.
examples: He gave a sheepish grin after realizing he had been pronouncing the word wrong for years.
She offered a sheepish apology for arriving thirty minutes late.

loyalty.definition: A strong feeling of support and allegiance to someone or something; faithfulness.
examples: Her loyalty to her friends was unwavering, even when it cost her professionally.
Brand loyalty can be a powerful force in consumer behavior.

impersonal.definition: Not influenced by personal feelings; lacking warmth or personality; cold and detached.
examples: The rejection letter was curt and impersonal, offering no explanation.
Large corporations are often criticized for their impersonal treatment of customers.

inexpressible.definition: Too great or intense to be expressed or conveyed in words.
examples: She felt an inexpressible joy when she held her newborn child for the first time.
The beauty of the landscape filled him with an inexpressible sense of peace.

fascinate.definition: To attract and hold the attention and interest of someone irresistibly.
examples: The documentary about deep-sea creatures fascinated viewers of all ages.
She was fascinated by the intricate patterns found in snowflakes.

harassment.definition: Aggressive pressure or intimidation; unwanted conduct that causes distress or discomfort.
examples: The company implemented strict policies against workplace harassment.
Online harassment has become a growing concern for social media platforms.

enliven.definition: To make something more lively, interesting, or cheerful; to animate.
examples: Fresh flowers and bright colors enlivened the otherwise drab waiting room.
Her witty commentary enlivened what would have been a boring presentation.

synthesize.definition: To combine separate elements or ideas into a coherent whole; to produce by chemical synthesis.
examples: The researcher synthesized data from dozens of studies to draw her conclusions.
The ability to synthesize information from multiple sources is essential for critical thinking.

prosperous.definition: Successful, especially in financial terms; flourishing and thriving.
examples: The once-struggling town became prosperous after the discovery of natural gas.
A prosperous nation is one that invests in the well-being of all its citizens.

subjectivity.definition: The quality of being based on personal opinions, feelings, or interpretations rather than external facts.
examples: The subjectivity of art criticism means that two experts can reach opposite conclusions.
A good journalist strives to minimize subjectivity in their reporting.

euphemism.definition: A mild or indirect word or expression substituted for one considered too harsh, blunt, or offensive.
examples: "Passed away" is a common euphemism for "died."
Politicians often use euphemisms to make unpopular policies sound more palatable.

precarious.definition: Not securely held or in position; dangerously likely to fall or collapse; uncertain and risky.
examples: The climbers found themselves in a precarious position on the icy ledge.
Many freelancers face a precarious financial situation without steady income.

pervade.definition: To spread through and be perceived in every part of something; to permeate.
examples: A sense of optimism pervaded the entire community after the good news.
The smell of fresh bread pervaded the house every Sunday morning.

aptitude.definition: A natural ability or talent; an inherent capacity to learn or do something well.
examples: She showed an early aptitude for mathematics that impressed her teachers.
The aptitude test helped identify which career paths might suit him best.

cohort.definition: A group of people with a shared characteristic or experience; a companion or associate.
examples: The study followed a cohort of patients over a ten-year period.
She and her cohort of graduates entered the workforce during a recession.

patriarchy.definition: A system of society or government in which men hold the power and women are largely excluded from it.
examples: Feminist scholars have long critiqued the structures of patriarchy in Western culture.
Breaking down the patriarchy requires systemic change, not just individual effort.

obsession.definition: An unhealthy and compulsive preoccupation with something or someone; a persistent fixation.
examples: His obsession with perfection often prevented him from finishing projects.
What began as a hobby quickly grew into a full-blown obsession.

concede.definition: To admit that something is true after first denying or resisting it; to surrender or yield.
examples: After reviewing the data, she had to concede that her hypothesis was wrong.
The candidate conceded the election with a gracious speech to his supporters.

lurk.definition: To remain hidden so as to wait in ambush; to be present in a latent or barely noticeable state.
examples: Danger lurked in every shadow of the abandoned warehouse.
Beneath his cheerful exterior, a deep sadness lurked.

beckon.definition: To make a gesture to encourage someone to come nearer or follow; to seem appealing or inviting.
examples: She beckoned him over with a wave of her hand.
The open road beckoned, and she could not resist the urge to explore.
beckon.metaphor: Opportunity does not always knock; sometimes it beckons from a distance.

expound.definition: To explain or present a theory or idea in detail; to elaborate on.
examples: The professor expounded on the philosophical implications of quantum mechanics.
She expounded her vision for the company at the annual shareholders meeting.

eclipse.definition: The obscuring of one celestial body by another; figuratively, a decline or loss of importance.
examples: The solar eclipse drew millions of viewers outside to watch the sky darken.
His later failures eclipsed the remarkable achievements of his early career.

permeate.definition: To spread throughout; to pass through or penetrate every part of something.
examples: The aroma of coffee permeated every room of the house.
A culture of accountability must permeate every level of the organization.

simulacrum.definition: An image or representation of someone or something; an unsatisfying imitation or substitute.
examples: The theme park was a simulacrum of a European village, charming but artificial.
What passed for debate was merely a simulacrum, with the outcome predetermined.

tout.definition: To promote or advertise energetically; to praise enthusiastically.
examples: The company touted its new product as a revolutionary breakthrough.
He was touted as the next great hope for the struggling political party.

incandescence.definition: The emission of light by a body due to high temperature; a glowing intensity of brilliance.
examples: The incandescence of the filament lit the room with a warm glow.
She performed with an incandescence that made the audience forget everything else.
incandescence.metaphor: There was an incandescence about her enthusiasm that lit up every conversation.
